slides.title: Basics of investing
body: What is investing?
By definition, investing is defined as:
Putting (money) into financial schemes, shares, property, or a commercial venture with the expectation of achieving a profit.
To simplify, you're giving some of your money into certain ideas which works by buying and selling, in the hopes of making a profit by doing so

slides.title: Different types of investing
body: -As we saw in the previous slides, we have different mechanisms to put money into which can turn a profit
But how do we differentiate between them?
-That's done under 2 different ways; the time, and its general convention in how investors invest
-Time-defined: Long term (e.g. Holding stocks long term) vs Short term (e.g. Day Trading)
-Convention-defined: Traditional (e.g. Bonds) vs Alternate (e.g. Crypto)
-In this course, you will primarily learn about Long term conventional investment methods such as Stocks and Bonds.
However in some cases, there are also short term offshoots you will also learn such as Day Trading

slides.title: Terminology
body: When it comes to investing, we may need to gloss over some small terms which have a major meaning that you may not have known.
This includes terms (aside from the investment method names) such as:
Limited Liability - If a firm goes bankrupt (has no money), you will only lose what you invested and not your own assets like your house
Portfolio - A collection of your investments which show your current prices and other relevant data

slides.title: Risks and Rewards
body: Note: While this website IS financial advice, it is also true that if you do choose to invest
because of this course, then be warned that investing is at your own risk, so don't invest more than you can afford to lose
However, this is not to discourage you to invest, it is encouraged, because when there is a negative, there is also a positive.
In this case, the positive is that there is a financial reward if you do invest properly using our advice, which can be high in certain cases.

slides.title: Time Horizon and Investing Goals
body: Time Horizon refers to the period which you wish to invest for, which is a necessity to know
before you start investing, which you should be establishing in your research phase of planning to invest
Investing goals are effectively simple goals like why are you investing in the first place.
These are important so that you enjoy the process, and are motivated to learn something new.

slides.title: Introduction to Stocks
body: What is a Stock?
-A stock is buying shares in a Public Limited Company from a specific market designed for this exchange
It allows you to not only receive a dividend, but also gives you some voting power, since it is 1 vote per share generally.
-Its price is generally based off its demand level for a given supply in issued shares.
E.g. When Boeing had difficulties with the 777MAX models, their stock price had significantly dropped.
This is because this was a fault at the hands of Boeing, which means that bad publicity will result in less demand in Boeing

slides.title: Types of Stock Trading
body: With stock trading, we must realise that there are multiple ways to trade stocks
One such way is Day Trading. This is when you are trading quite quickly and buying/selling based on price differentials in a short period of time
Another way is Long term holding, when you hold a stock for a much longer period of time and sell on a predicted maximised profit.
Algorithmic Trading is an adaptable strategy that you can use by creating an algorithm (a complex process for newbies)
in order to make a profit, where the computer trades for you. It is more used in short term trading due to the computer's quicker-than-humans trading speeds

slides.title: Fundamental Stock Analysis
body: Fundamental Stock Analysis is a method of analysing stocks in the longer range of things.
It involves:
-Analysing a company's methods of making money
-Ensuring that over a certain holding period, that stock will increase in value
Reviewing the accounts they publish to ensure their finances seem set (ie it's a safe investment if you look at ratios such as gearing)

slides.title: Technical Stock Analysis
body: Technical Stock analysis primarily involves the use of Stock Movement Indicators (such as MACD, RSI, OBV)
in order to make a guess as to how a stock would move based on how a stock has been moving over a certain time period.
It can be used in both short term and long term (depending on the set timeframe), and generally graph the results to get a clearer picture, like the picture in this slide

slides.title: Stock Orders
body: When we want to buy or sell stocks, we must place an 'order'.
This order is effectively an instruction that once we reach a certain price on the order book (shown below), we do an action we want
There are multiple ways to implement these actions, which is either a limit order, or a market order generally
Limit orders are orders that are only executed until the best price has reached a certain price on the order book
these orders do not necessarily terminate unless you use a specific order called a 'fill and kill' order, which clears your orders for later.
A Market order is an order like a limit order, however, it will not stop and instead will 'fill out' the order regardless of price

slides.title: Portfolio Management
body: Managing a stock portfolio generally refers to maintaining track of how your investments are doing.
This includes methods such as Diversifying your portfolio into different sectors eg Software, Consumer Discretionary, etc,
as well as rebalancing your portfolio.
It also refers to avoiding mistakes such as not trading to a plan, emotional trading, and not cutting your losses quickly.
Another thing to remember is not to fall for scams, which generally happen through dodgy links (be sure you connect to HTTPS before paying for anything).

slides.title: Staying Informed
body: Staying informed is one thing that is the most important thing with trading stocks,
as you are able to make pre-empted decisions on stock orders (like to buy or to sell a stock).
One of the best ways to stay informed is primarily through watching the news to see what is happening around different sectors
I recommend you follow Bloomberg/The Economist (as below) for this, as they are quite business-focused generally
